Quantitative and Qualitative Data Analysis: Leveraging statistical techniques, formulas, and calculations using R and Python to derive meaningful insights.
Data Collection Pipelines: Experience with Open Data Kit (ODK) and Kobo Toolbox.
Statistical Analysis: Proficient in statistics and packages including Microsoft Excel, STATA, SPSS, SAS, R, Python, and EViews for comprehensive dataset analysis.
Pattern and Trend Analysis: Using advanced statistical tools to identify, analyze, and interpret patterns and trends in complex data sets, aiding in diagnostics and predictions.
Data Cleaning and Visualization: Utilizing R and Python for comprehensive data cleaning, analysis, and visualization.
Machine Learning Predictive Models: Developing robust predictive models using both R and Python.
Data Visualization: Creating static and interactive maps, dashboards, and visualizations using Leaflet, Shiny, Matplotlib, Seaborn, Plotly, and ggplot2.
Interactive Web Applications: Building dynamic applications for visualization and analysis with R Shiny and Python Shiny.
Power BI Expertise: Designing and creating insightful dashboards and reports for effective business intelligence.
Dynamic Reporting: Crafting and publishing interactive, reproducible documents, dashboards, and websites with Quarto.
Project Management: Efficiently managing data science projects using GitHub for version control and collaboration.
Statistical Software Training: Providing training on statistical software such as SPSS and R, covering various topics.

title: Projects
text: The Childhood Micronutrient Deficiency Prediction App is an interactive tool built with R Shiny that predicts childhood micronutrient deficiency. This application predicts childhood micronutrient deficiency using machine learning. It employs an XGBoost model trained on various demographic and health-related features. The model was developed using the tidymodels framework and demonstrates good predictive performance. Furthermore, the model has been deployed to ensure accessibility and ease of use for healthcare providers and researchers. Access the app here: Childhood Micronutrient Deficiency Prediction Tool

title: Projects
text: The Childhood Micronutrient Deficiency Prediction App is an interactive tool built with R Shiny that predicts childhood micronutrient deficiency. This application predicts childhood micronutrient deficiency using machine learning. It employs an XGBoost model trained on various demographic and health-related features. The model was developed using the tidymodels framework and demonstrates good predictive performance. Furthermore, the model has been deployed to ensure accessibility and ease of use for healthcare providers and researchers. Access the app here: Childhood Micronutrient Deficiency Prediction Tool

title: Projects
section: Customer Churn Prediction App (R Shiny App)
text:
Customer Churn Prediction App (R Shiny App)






The Customer Churn Prediction App is an interactive tool built with R Shiny that predicts customer churn in the telecommunications sector. This application employs the XGBoost algorithm, integrated with the tidymodels framework, to analyze customer attributes and behaviors, providing insights into churn probability for subscribers of telecom services. Access the app here: Customer Churn Prediction Tool

title: Projects
section: Spatial distribution of childhood MN deficiency
text:
Spatial distribution of childhood MN deficiency


The interactive spatial map showed that the spatial variation of childhood micronutrient (MN) deficiency in Ethiopia was most prevalent in the Somali, Afar, and Amhara regions, while the Gambela, Addis Ababa, and Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples (SNNP) regions had the lowest prevalence of MN deficiency.Link

title: Projects
section: COVID-19 Dashboard: The case of Ethiopia
text:
COVID-19 Dashboard: The case of Ethiopia






This dashboard provides an overview of the Coronavirus (COVID-19) epidemic for Ethiopia. It is built with R using Quarto framework. Check out the Covid-19 dashboard

title: Leykun Getaneh Gebeye
text:
I am Leykun Getaneh Gebeye is a senior lecturer, data scientist, data analyst, and statistician with expertise in machine learning, time series analysis, and big data analysis. I hold a BSc and a MSc in Statistics, and am certified in data science specialization. With over 7 years of experience as a lecturer at Wollo University in Ethiopia, I have extensive experience in teaching, advising, and conducting research. I actively contribute to training programs and workshops related to statistical software and am proficient in a wide range of statistical software and programming languages, including R and Python.
In addition to my core data science and statistical skillset, I have recently expanded my technical capabilities to include Quarto, cross-language R/Python workflows, and interactive data visualizations. This breadth of expertise enables me to effectively preprocess, analyze, and communicate complex data insights, with specialties in machine learning, time series analysis, and big data.
My research interests include:

machine learning,
time Series Analysis,

big data analysis,

disease prediction,

survival analysis,

joint modeling, and

nutrition.

title: Central Limit Theorem (CLT) shiny app demo with quarto
text:
This interactive Shiny app demonstrates the Central Limit Theorem (CLT) using a dynamic histogram. The CLT states that the distribution of the sample mean will be approximately normally distributed, regardless of the original distribution, given a sufficiently large sample size.
This visualization helps in understanding how the sample mean converges to a normal distribution as the number of samples increases.
The app is built using the shiny and shinylive r packages.









Note



Please wait a few seconds to see the App!


#| standalone: true
#| viewerHeight: 600
library(shiny)
library(bslib)

theme <- bs_theme(font_scale = 1.5)

# Define UI for app that draws a histogram ----
ui <- page_sidebar(theme = theme,
  sidebar = sidebar(open = "open",
    numericInput("n", "Sample size", 100),
    checkboxInput("pause", "Pause", FALSE),
  ),
  plotOutput("plot", width=1100)
)

server <- function(input, output, session) {
  data <- reactive({
    input$resample
    if (!isTRUE(input$pause)) {
      invalidateLater(1000)
    }
    rnorm(input$n)
  })
  
  output$plot <- renderPlot({
    hist(data(),
         breaks = 40,
         xlim = c(-3, 3),
         ylim = c(0, 0.5),
         col = 'skyblue',
         border = 'white',
         xlab = "Value",
         freq = FALSE,
         main = "Central Limit Theorem Demonstration",
         cex.lab = 1.2,
         cex.axis = 1.1,
         cex.main = 1.4
    )
    
    x <- seq(from = -3, to = 3, length.out = 500)
    y <- dnorm(x)
    lines(x, y, lwd = 2, col = 'darkgreen')
    
    lwd <- 3
    abline(v = 0, col = "red", lwd = lwd, lty = 2)
    abline(v = mean(data()), col = "blue", lwd = lwd, lty = 1)
    
    legend("topright", legend = c("Normal Distribution", "Population Mean", "Sample Mean"),
           col = c("darkgreen", "red", "blue"),
           lty = c(1, 2, 1),
           lwd = c(2, lwd, lwd),
           bty = "n",
           cex = 1.1,
           text.font = 1.5
    )
    
    grid(nx = NULL, ny = NULL, col = "lightgray", lty = "dotted")
  }, res = 140)
}

# Create Shiny app ----
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
